title: Cows are being painted with zebra stripes to test odd theory - and it works
text:

Cows worldwide are in a constant battle with biting flies.

The irritating insects cause cows all sorts of problems, such as reduced levels of grazing, feeding and sleeping.

Flies also increase repelling behaviours in cows like head throwing, foot stamping and tail swishing, leading to higher levels of stress.

But scientists seem to have found a way to reduce the irritation flies cause to cows - by painting them to look like zebra.

In a study published by Plos One , they tested the theory that black and white stripes acted as a deterrent to flies by confusing the bugs' senses.

(Image: Kojima et al)

Six Japanese Black cows were chosen for the project, with two painted with black and white stripes, two left as normal old fashioned cows and two painted with just black stripes as a control to ensure it wasn't the type of paint that was repelling the flies.

Painting each moo-er took one person roughly five minutes.

The cows were observed for three days and the experiment was repeated twice, with all the cows getting a go at trying each of the roles.

(Image: Kojima et al)

Incredibly, the cows masquerading as zebra experienced almost half the number of biting flies landing on them than the other two.

The black and white painted cows also showed a lot less fly-repelling behaviours, with just under 40 every half an hour compared to 53.

In its conclusion, the study says that biting flies are the most damaging pests of cattle worldwide and can prove to be a costly problem to tackle.

Pesticides are widely used in a bid to beat the problem, but insects often evolve a resistance to a new pesticide within about 10 years.

It states that painting cows with black and white stripes instead provides defence against biting flies using a method that is more beneficial to the environment and human health.

So don't be too surprised if the field near you is full of cows painted as zebra in the future.
description: Biting flies cause huge problems for cows, but scientists may have found a very strange way to combat the problem
